awd_titl_txt: EAGER:   Model-Free Classification of Collective Behavior Based on Automated Detection of Symmetry from Video Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project brings together an expert in emergent dynamics in animal collectives with an expert in automated scientific discovery. Automated discovery concerns the search for underlying patterns -- specifically, the search for symmetry -- in observed data. Symmetry refers to the property of remaining unchanged under relocation or reorientation, and many fundamental physical laws exhibit some type of symmetry. This project will extend methods for finding symmetries in measured motion to apply to raw video data. This extension will then be applied to videos of animals moving singly and in flocks, schools, or swarms. The results will be used to understand how collective motion is related to, and different from, individual motion, and which common factors relate collective motion in different animals. The results will have value for safe and effective performance of engineered multi-agent systems, such as platoons of self-driving cars, robots interacting with human groups, and swarms of quadrotor drones.

This project seeks to develop a quantitative method to discriminate and measure collective behavior in multi-agent systems using an automated discovery algorithm, based on "dynamical kinds," which are defined in terms of the dynamic symmetries of a system, and have been used to assess whether a pair of time series are realizations of the same governing dynamics. The existing algorithm can analyze time series from coupled dynamical systems. For this project, the algorithm will be applied to data from animals, individually and in groups. To accommodate the most widely available form of data, the algorithm will be modified to take raw video directly as input. The algorithm will be used to explore individual versus collective behavior in selected numerical models, and in video data from biological swarms. Finally, the algorithm will be used across a multi-species dataset, to quantitatively relate animal groups and their models across species and behaviors. The method created here will constitute a powerful protocol for model validation, and will offer insight into differences between collective behaviors exhibited by animals groups, both within and between species.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
Collective behavior in animal groups is a striking phenomenon that is easy to identify for a human observer, but is difficult to quantitatively describe in all its possible forms. The goal of this project was to enable an algorithm for automated scientific discovery, EUGENE, for use with data from animal groups and to use it to describe collective behaviors. EUGENE is an algorithm which measures the so-called “dynamical kind” of a dataset, which is a quantitative description of the type of system that generated it. The power of this project lies in the fact that it does not depend on a human-defined model of collective behavior, and thus has the potential to capture relationships between animal group behaviors that may be inextricable using other methods.

In working towards this goal, we created a database of animal group motion from species of birds, insects, fish, and mammals. We adapted EUGENE to use this data. Specifically, we enabled the algorithm to use video data without tracking the motion of individual animals in the group. In addition, we showed that measuring the relationships between animal groups captured by EUGENE didn’t require information on three-dimensional motion but only multiple two-dimensional perspectives. This is analogous to using multiple camera angles to assess three-dimensional motion, but without reconstructing the trajectories of motion in three dimensions. Both of these advances greatly reduced the work of applying EUGENE, and potentially other similar analytical techniques, by not necessitating tracking individuals in two or three dimensions. In light of these advances, EUGENE is now accessible for use with data from animal group motion captured in less technically laborious ways, which means that it can be used to test hypotheses about animal group motion that are relevant to biologists.

This project has impacted the development of human resources through its support of student training. Through this work, two PhD students and two masters students have been a part of the interdisciplinary project team. In addition, one post-doctoral fellow has gained experience in both research and student mentoring, and has subsequently become a tenure-track faculty member in a STEM field. 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Nicole Abaid
